32.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, coming to
you from that country over there, Australia.

39.text:
Coming up from down under -one of the country's
most sporting states is opening up a wealth

45.text:
of deer hunting for international visitors.
We find out what's on offer.

49.text:
We're guests of Winchester Australia and they
love duck hunting

54.text:
We're at Australia's biggest shooting show
to find out what Aussies love to do when they're

59.text:
not losing at cricket or complaining about
their prime minister.

62.text:
First, let's leave the sea, find a deer and
maybe a roo too.

68.text:
The Australian states of Victoria and South
Australia have some of the best deerstalking

72.text:
you will find anywhere in the world. From
July 2013, Victoria is shedding a great wodge

79.text:
of bureaucracy that stops international hunters
from coming here. I'm out to see what's going

85.text:
to be on offer with the help of pro deerstalker
Mark Reams.

90.text:
Deer stalking is pretty big here now, it is
quite popular, there is a lot more deer around

96.text:
now, than there has been in previous years.
It is getting quite popular now.

101.text: What are we after this morning.

103.text:
We are going to go down the bush line here
and have a look for a fallow deer. There are

108.text:
quite a few in this area. Some good stags
have been shot here. With any luck we will

110.text:
wander down there and hopefully run into a
couple and see how we go.

116.text:
You only have fallow deer here, what else
...

119.text:
We have red deer here as well. Not as many.
They are easily noticed so they get shot,

127.text: but fallow are coming on quite good here.

130.text:
Species include chital, hog deer, red deer
and this one, Sambar.

136.text:
One of the eight deer species is fallow. Mark
filmed this old boy during the rut, which

141.text:
takes place in April. It wasn't long before
Mark came back. This is a sportsman's paradise.

149.text:
Now a fallow herd can be tough to get near
to, with so many eyes alert for danger.

153.text:
We have got some deer just over the rise here,
about 300 yards down. I think with the dirt

159.text:
trails we might get back into the bush line
here, creep down very quietly and have a look

166.text:
and see if there is a trophy animal here.
If not see if we can get a nice eating one

176.text:
In Australian-rules deer hunting they employ
an Aussie early alert system. Not only are

181.text:
we trying to outwit the deer but the marsupials
are keen to sound the alert if things aren't

186.text:
right. A happy kangaroo means happy deer.
So that means we have to head into the bush

193.text:
There are like 50 kangaroos down there. Plus
the deer we have got 50 to 60 sets of eyes

201.text:
watching out for us. So we will sneak up through
the cover as quiet as we can and see how we

204.text:
We don't want them to get the bounce on us.
The bounce ...

212.text:
We have to be silent. However, we are in a
gumtree wood, and gumtrees like to keep down

217.text:
the competition by occasionally bursting into
flames. They create that effect by shedding

223.text:
dry bark and branches, and waiting for someone
to drop a cigarette in the wrong place during

228.text:
the dry season. It means we are walking on
what is effectively kindling.

233.text:
Still - what do I know about the natural environment?
We hear this.

248.text:
It was a koala. He is calling out for his
girlfriends.

252.text:
Despite the wildlife of the Pacific Rim conspiring
against us, we manage to get into position.

258.text:
But they haven't invented a bullet that passes
accurately through eucalyptus, so Mark says

263.text:
we have to move one dry tree trunk nearer.
And that's our mistake. We trip the kangaroo

269.text:
security beam - and they're off, taking the
deer with them.

273.text:
So nothing mucks up your morning's stalking
like kangaroos do.

278.text:
So can you come and hunt deer here? Yes you
can. All the deer species are introduced from

284.text:
somewhere, none are A-grade Australian wildlife,
so stalking them is something the Government

290.text:
So we are trying to open and grow that market
and we really encourage people to come to

294.text:
this country and take advantage particularly
of our wonderful game resources in Victoria.

297.text:
Basically, Victoria is open for business as
far as hunting is concerned.

301.text:
Open for business. We would love to see any
international visitor here. Lots of Australians

305.text:
go over seas. We would like to see that come
the other way as well.

309.text:
Like South Africa and the springbok, Ireland
and the red stag, and the Bahamas and the

314.text:
blue marlin, Australia belongs to a long list
of countries around the world that hunts its

322.text:
Kangaroos have reached plague proportions
in many parts of Australia. But Australian

326.text:
shooters and the Australian government take
kangaroo culls extremely seriously. There

331.text:
is a great layer of regulation before anyone
is allowed to shoot a roo, and farms have

337.text:
to apply for a 'destruction permit'. Mark
takes us to on one such farm.

343.text:
It's not long before a mob of kangaroos cross
our path and we drop one where it stands using

350.text: There are a lot of these animals aren't there?

355.text:
Kangaroos, yes. Especially now in the southern
parts of Australia. Southern grey kangaroo.

361.text:
Due to the farmers opening up all the countryside.
Their numbers have exploded. Now the government

368.text:
issues permits to have them shot, otherwise
they just eat all the food and die in mass

373.text:
numbers. Now they shoot them under the permit
system. It is an option farmers have now and

380.text: help them clear out the land a little bit.

382.text:
Whereas other things like rabbits, feral pigs
in the northern territories there is a kind

389.text: of wipe clean order isn't there.

391.text:
Yes an open ... type thing where they just
want to eradicate entirely. With the kangaroo

396.text: it is under a more managed programme.

398.text:
It is an incredible animal. We have no famous
reference for this in the UK at all. But look

405.text:
at these extraordinary hind legs for getting
around on.

409.text:
Half the kangaroos legs muscles develop for
bounding are able to stabilise as it hops

417.text:
and small front legs which are near useless
only for grasping things, but as they say

422.text:
they can travel huge distances in shorts amount
of time. They are perfectly designed for the

427.text: And you can't build a kangaroo proof fence.

430.text:
No, a six foot fence is nothing for a kangaroo
to jump. A normal farm fence like these ones

438.text:
Tell me about the eating of these things.
That looks like a reasonably good leg.

444.text:
Now in Australia they are shot by professionals
for the human consumption trade. So now that

451.text:
you can have kangaroos that have been processed
in an abattoir and you can buy selected cuts

460.text:
Any game, lean, high in protein, low in fat.
It is a very good quality meat.

468.text:
We came for deer but we ended up with a kangaroo
and we did try roo meat that night. It was

473.text:
certainly lean but the rib-eye steak was more
appealing.

477.text:
And don't forget that deer stalking in Victoria
will be open to all international hunters

485.text:
And no you don't have to swing through like
this, boing, boing, boing, bang - now I couldn't

493.text:
leave him behind it's David on the fieldsports
channel news stump

506.text:
You heard it here first - Australia is open
for hunting business - but the new laws coming

511.text:
in in July are not just about encouraging
foreigners to hunt. The state of Victoria

515.text:
has brought in a raft of - no - not laws - but
relaxations of laws, encouraging kids aged

520.text:
12 to 17 to go hunting, extending the red
deer season from two months to the whole year

525.text:
and allowing the use of terriers while you
are deer hunting. Follow the link on the screen

530.text:
As accident in South Australia is the reason
sport hunting should be banned across the

535.text:
country, say Australian anti-hunting groups.
A man carrying out a cull of feral goats was

539.text:
shot in the ankle. New South Wales opposition
environment spokesman Luke Foley says the

544.text:
accident is "further confirmation of the dangers
of allowing amateur hunters in national parks."

549.text:
An Australian TV interview about gun control
with two shock jocks did not go as expected

556.text:
- and the clip is now doing the rounds on
the internet. The pundits on Channel 7's Sunrise

561.text:
programme were expected to come down heavily
in favour of banning guns - but they both

565.text:
agreed that Australian gun laws were tough
enough, prompting this reaction from the studio.

570.text:
The majority of gun owners are highly responsible
and they are not going to do the kinds of

578.text:
Australia is to get a new angling attraction.
The museum has been developed in a historic

583.text:
house at Evandale, near Launceston, and covers
the history of fly fishing across three states.

588.text:
Trout were first introduced to Tasmania in
the 1860s.

593.text:
Greenpeace is under fire from the Australian
media and Government after it tried and failed

598.text:
to run a TV advertising campaign against Coca-Cola.
The commercial, now running on YouTube, was

604.text:
due to run on Austraia's Channel Nine TV station.
It shows people drinking Coca Cola from plastic

609.text:
bottles followed by images of dead birds falling
from the sky, claiming the company is bullying

614.text:
politicians into blocking a deposit scheme
for drink containers, and that waste plastic

618.text: bottles are therefore killing sea birds.

622.text:
And finally two Australian hunters got the
surprise of their lives when they reviewed

626.text:
the footage from their trailcam. We tracked
down Danny Galea, who is prominent in the

630.text:
Australian gun trade, and it would appear
he goes to great length to wind up his hunting

637.text:
... it was in between the glove and the suit
so, I was pretending to shake the tree and

642.text: the watch was going like that.

645.text:
Not really sure it was the watch that gave
the game away!!

648.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

659.text:
Thank you David - Just one Hallo Charlie this
week. Thanks to everyone else who sent one

664.text: in - we'll run them next week.

667.text:
Hallo there David. It is not it is Hallo Charlie
isn't it? Hallo Charlie. I am over here in

680.text:
Australia, no I am not actually. I am sitting
here with Roy because you left us behind.

684.text:
And we are sitting here having to console
ourselves by eating lemon drizzle cake. I

689.text:
am pretty upset. I was just looking at this
map of Australia thinking about all the lovely

693.text:
times we could be having over there. Even
an invitation would have been something wouldn't

697.text:
it? Just the thought would have been lovely.
But no.

698.text:
Yes, thanks. I didn't even know you had gone.
Just like the time when my parents dropped

702.text:
even say good bye. Where is Crow? If you have
got Crow out there with you.

703.text:
Is he out there in his budgie snugglers. No
not a nice thought is it.

715.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself
on your mobile phone and just a sentence saying

720.text:
Hallo Charlie, who you are and what you are
up to. Then share it or email it via Youtube,

726.text:
Facebook, Dropbox, Yousendit, Younameit to
Charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

While the cats away...... right what's next

of getting off the plane I was crouching by

I wouldn't want to be Australian duck at this

here. Have a little bit of a driven shoot.

I'm with Casey Poletti, a modest bloke who

768.text:
Now I am expecting great things from you.

As a junior which in Australia is up to the

784.text:

some other countries and some different environments

Casey works for Outdoor Sporting Agencies

.It's a very different gun to Casey's competition

off with style. We've got more duck shooting

825.text: Thank you. So that is the black duck.

They are actually not bad eating those ones.

834.text:
About the same size of our mallard. This is

837.text:
That is a drake. So the score board ticking

840.text: So we are out for a duck.

841.text: Super, see if we can get some more.

We have got more duck shooting later in the

848.text:
Now we are here to find out what this country
has got to offer. One of the best places to

852.text:
do that is the biggest shooting show in Australia.
It is Shot expo in Melbourne.

868.text:
There is not much kit under this roof that

the world. There are of course the big global
names that most will be familiar with - but

877.text:
what is the traditional Aussie hunter looking
for?

881.text:
It all depends what section you are in. What
state you are in will determine what calibre

886.text:
because obviously you have got pigs, you have

We occasionally hear about duck bans in New
South Wales and gun bans and things like that.

898.text:
Is that trend still heading that way or is
the tide turned.

901.text:
I think it is turning, because you don't see,

906.text:
they were continuously on TV whenever there
was a duck opening. You don't get them on

TV any more. They are still very loud, but

917.text:
The Australian hunting community is not without
its problems. To try and meet what they call

921.text:
the 'extreme greens' on a parliamentary playing
field, shooters and fishers created a new

926.text: party that's now on the political radar.

929.text:
We already ... Australian context, don't represent
anything green. What they basically are is

934.text:
communists and centralists in control artists.
And what they think they can do is influence

941.text:
the shut down of almost everything in the
country and the country orientated industries

946.text:
like forestry, agriculture, they want to control
all the water all this sort of stuff.

Now if you joined the Shooters and fishers

- so let's see if I can get a tune out of

Too much like this. Bit further in your mouth.

972.text:
Getting there. More like this. Too hard, slow

979.text: Oh fabulous. Thank you very much.

Across the way from the Shooters and fishers

Incredibly there's been no hunting screened

to get on the billing with his new series,

998.text:
Beyond the Divide focuses on the real adventure

country kind of experiences and all the background

roots level, being out there with your mates,

Lovely. We have got Australian viewers, so

one inch scope 2:15, 5:25 magnification and

So you are looking to hunting in really big

Judging by the numbers the show is a great

Another big aussie passion is duck hunting
and for a few short months normally dedicated

1192.text:
responsible reliable members of society turn

It would appear that Aussie duck hunters are

their own children for a chance of sitting
by a muddy puddle in the hope that one of

1229.text:
the country's eight species will come their
way.

1232.text:
This morning we've been invited out by Glen
from Winchester Australia to one of this favourite

1236.text:
spots with his mates the two Pauls, who are
equal duck nuts.

1241.text:
Well it is a tiny little pond and we are lucky
enough that we are near a river system. In

1250.text:
some large water pondage which is nearby which

1254.text:
coming in and get stirred off the river and

They are all Browning and Winchestered up.
Glen has been developing his own duck load

1267.text:
specifically for Australia but, until the

1271.text:

- a cartridge we first came across at its

1277.text:
It is a brand new technology - lead free,
steel shot. Its real claim to fame is it is

1283.text:
hex shot it is not round like normal steel
shot is. So it has a lot of edges and corners

1290.text:
that upon impact deposits a lot more energy
than a standard round steel pellet would.

1459.text:
modified in the USA for coyotes and Africa

he says - and I won't attempt the accent.

1476.text:
As we have discovered at Fieldsports Channel,
deer hunting is one of Australia's top hunting

1480.text:
sports, mainly in the south of the country.
Hunting deer in the land of Oz, set to Jon

1484.text: Bon Jovi, is a good example.

1486.text:
In the north of the country, it's all about
ferals, especially pigs. People would not

1490.text:
use the old clich� 'plague proportions'
if they had seen Australia's pig problem.

scratching the surface by by culling feral

1498.text:
pigs on a property in Queensland with a pump
